speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your fatigue? Is it constant or does it come and go?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's been constant, doc. I just feel like I don't have the energy to do anything anymore. Even simple tasks feel like climbing a mountain."

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any changes in your appetite or weight recently?

speaker: Patient
text: "I've lost a bit of weight, doc. I've been eating the same, but I just can't seem to keep anything down. And to be honest, I've been having some trouble sleeping too."

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any coughing or shortness of breath lately?

speaker: Patient
text: "Actually, doc, I have been having some trouble breathing lately. It's like I'm not getting enough air. And sometimes I feel like I'm choking on my own saliva. It's really unsettling."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you describe the abdominal pain you've been experiencing? Is it constant or does it come and go?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's been getting worse over the past few weeks, doc. It's a dull ache, mostly in the middle of my belly. Sometimes it feels like it's radiating to my back, but it's hard to pinpoint exactly where it is. It's been bothering me more at night, and it's been keeping me up."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me when the night sweats started and how often you're experiencing them?

speaker: Patient
text: "About a month ago, doc. At first, it was just occasional, but lately, it's been almost every night. I wake up drenched in sweat, and it's really uncomfortable. I've been using extra blankets to try and stay warm, but it's still a struggle."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've had any recent exposure to anyone with a similar illness or if you've traveled to any areas with a high incidence of infectious diseases recently?

speaker: Patient
text: "No, doc, I haven't been around anyone with a similar illness. And as for travel, I haven't left the country in years, just occasional trips to nearby cities for work. But I have been working a lot of overtime lately, maybe 12 hours a day, 6 days a week. Could that be contributing to my symptoms?"

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any unusual lumps or swelling in your neck, armpits, or groin area? (Please respond with the patient's answer)

speaker: Patient
text: "Actually, doc, I have noticed some swelling in my neck. It's been getting worse over the past few days, and it's been causing me some discomfort. I've been trying to ignore it, but it's hard to ignore when I'm looking in the mirror and seeing it there."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the swelling in your neck? Is it tender to the touch or is it more of a firm lump?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's a bit of both, doc. It's firm to the touch, but if I press on it, it does feel a bit tender. It's also a bit warm to the touch, which is weird. I've never had any swelling in my neck before, so I'm not sure what's causing it."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've had any recent exposure to tuberculosis or have you been around anyone who has it?

speaker: Patient
text: "I don't think so, doc. I mean, I've been around some coworkers who have been coughing a lot lately, but I don't know if that's related to tuberculosis. Like I said, I've been working a lot of overtime, maybe that's just making me more susceptible to getting sick or something."

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any changes in your skin or nails recently?

speaker: Patient
text: "My skin feels really dry and itchy, doc. And my nails are brittle and breaking easily. I've also been getting these weird, tiny bumps on my arms and legs. They're not itchy or painful, just annoying."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you show me the exact location of the swelling in your neck?

speaker: Patient
text: "Okay, doc. Let me show you. *lifts chin* See, it's right here, just below my jawline. It's a bit lumpy, and it feels... weird. Like it's not supposed to be there."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've had any recent exposure to anyone with a history of cancer or if you've had any family history of cancer?

speaker: Patient
text: "Actually, doc, my father passed away from lung cancer a few years ago. And my grandfather had some kind of cancer too, I'm not really sure what kind. But as for recent exposure, I don't think so. Like I said, I've been working a lot of overtime and haven't really been around anyone with a history of cancer."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you show me the exact location of the enlarged lymph node?

speaker: Patient
text: "Right here, doc. *lifts chin* See, it's just below my jawline. It's a bit lumpy and feels... unusual. Like it's not supposed to be there."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the dry, itchy skin you've been experiencing? Is it limited to certain areas of your body or is it widespread?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's pretty widespread, doc. My arms, legs, and chest are all affected. It's not just dry, it's also really itchy. I've been using lotion and creams to try and moisturize, but it doesn't seem to be helping much. And to be honest, it's been getting worse over the past few weeks."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've noticed any changes in your stool or urine lately?

speaker: Patient
text: "Actually, doc, I have noticed that my stool has been a bit... loose lately. It's not diarrhea or anything, but it's definitely not as solid as it used to be. And as for urine, I've been having to get up in the middle of the night to go a lot more often than usual. It's like my body is constantly trying to get rid of something, but I don't know what."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the loose stools you've been experiencing? Is it accompanied by any blood or mucus in your stool?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's just loose, doc. No blood or mucus that I've noticed. It's just... runny, I guess. And it's been happening pretty regularly, not just once in a while. Sometimes I'll go a few days without having a normal bowel movement, and then I'll have a few loose ones in a row. It's been really frustrating, to be honest."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your work and the type of work you do? Is it physically demanding or do you have to sit for long periods of time?

speaker: Patient
text: "I work in construction, doc. I'm a laborer, so I'm on my feet all day, lifting heavy objects and doing physical labor. It's a demanding job, but I'm used to it. I've been doing it for years. Lately, though, it's been feeling even more exhausting than usual. Like I'm not getting enough oxygen or something. And my body aches all the time, even when I'm not working."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've noticed any difficulty swallowing or hoarseness in your voice lately?

speaker: Patient
text: "Actually, doc, I have noticed that swallowing can be a bit of a struggle sometimes. It's like food gets stuck in my throat, and I have to swallow a few times to get it down. And my voice has been feeling a bit hoarse lately too. It's not too bad, but it's definitely noticeable."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the sensation of food getting stuck in your throat when you swallow? Is it a frequent occurrence or just occasional?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's been happening more frequently, doc. Lately, it feels like every time I eat, I have to swallow multiple times to get the food down. It's like my esophagus is trying to push it back up or something. And it's not just with solid foods, even liquids can get stuck sometimes. It's really uncomfortable and makes me feel like I'm not eating properly."

speaker: Doctor
text: REQUEST TEST: Chest X-Ray

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS
